--- title: "Immortal time bias - \"The fallacy that never dies\" (Part 1)" date: 2024-02-09 categories: [concept, survival] #image: description: "Learn why this misclassification of time in a survival analysis can seriously bias your results." --- In 2001, a [paper](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11352696/ "https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11352696/"){style="color: #1a0dab"} published in the *Annals of Internal Medicine* reported that Oscar winners had a longer life expectancy - by about **4 years** - compared to their less successful peers. The authors conclusions were that: **"The association of high status with increased longevity that prevails in the public also extends to celebrities, contributes to a large survival advantage, and is partially explained by factors related to success."** The study received widespread attention in the media, with one future Oscar winner acknowledging the work in her acceptance [speech](https://www.thecut.com/2015/02/oscar-winners-really-live-longer.html "https://www.thecut.com/2015/02/oscar-winners-really-live-longer.html"){style="color: #1a0dab"}. The problem was that the reported survival advantage was illusory, and the reason for this was an invalid analysis that has been repeated many times in the [literature](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17252614/ "https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17252614/"){style="color: #1a0dab"}. Winners given credit for survival as winners before they won. Winning can't possibly have contributed to this portion of their survival. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dat <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pgseye/data/main/heart.csv", header = T) #data(heart, package="survival") head(dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
